data.title: Select debug program and switch between running debug programs

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Its a feature request. Debugging multiple programs without using a mouse.

So far you can only start one preselected debug program with F5.
Its not possible without using a mouse to select a specific debug program, even to focus it with cursor or tab navigation.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5102094/23212747/74bb569e-f908-11e6-9356-d1ad5a260f7d.png)

Same if you run multiple programs in debug you cannot switch between them to e.g. restart

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5102094/23212786/82003f72-f908-11e6-9de6-b2444ef6438a.png)

Thank you.

data.title: Long lines are wrapped even though word wrap is turned off
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Disable word wrap in the user settings
2. Create a new file
3. Enter a very long text line

---

It appears that VS Code has a column at which it will wrap a line even though word wrap is disabled.
The line wrap doesn't change when I resize the window, it's always wrapped at column 301. This is very annoying when viewing large XML files.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1318438/23211898/82990bb6-f904-11e6-86d6-a9c126dbc6f6.png)

data.title: Markdown preview size is off when editor zoom is not the default
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-09T00:26:45.394Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions:

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code, open a new file
2. Type the following: * Hello world!
3. Save the file as Test.md
4. Press Ctrl+P, and use the following command: Markdown: Open preview to the side. This opens a preview of the markdown on the right side.
5. Zoom in the editor with CTRL + NUMPAD_PLUS, and zoom out with CTRL + NUMPAD_MINUS
The markdown preview will be off. If you zoom in, the content area will be smaller that it could be, and if you zoom out, the content area is off the screen.

data.title: When using Run to Cursor, then there is no inline instruction pointer decoration

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
Testing #20793 

I would have expected to see an inline instruction pointer decoration when I use the 'Run to Cursor' command.

![run-to-cursor](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/172399/23210926/e1e8dbbe-f8ff-11e6-9fd4-f3f684424baf.gif)

data.title: The instruction pointer is not visible (covered by the column break point decoration)
data.body:
Testing #20793

Notice that in the following setup the debugger has stopped before the 3rd console.log statement, but the instruction pointer decoration is not visible, it is covered by the column break point. 

The instruction pointer should be rendered on top of the breakpoint or use a composed decoration as is done in the line gutter.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/172399/23210468/fc710a3a-f8fd-11e6-8253-71076219cc27.png)

This is how the execution is rendered without the column breakpoint 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/172399/23210613/af4aa0ee-f8fe-11e6-8c37-38fffad60c3d.png)

data.title: Debug: exception when "toggle skipping this file"
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. debug a node application (in this case my standup app)
2. hit a "break on error" condition
3. right click into stack frame and pick "toggle skipping this file"

Console shows:

```
shell.ts:426 unrecognized request: Error: unrecognized request
    at file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-browser/workbench.main.js:95:2583
    at Object.v [as _notify] (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-browser/workbench.main.js:32:11161)

```

data.title: Debug: breakpoint from second application does not cause window to take focus
data.body: Not sure if this is intentional but when I debug 2 apps at the same time and the first app is paused on a breakpoint, letting the second app hit a breakpoint does not bring focus to the debugger and reveal the hit breakpoint.

data.title: Generated JSDoc comments should be a snippet with placeholders/variables
Attaching to Node running in inspector mode cannot determine version
data.body:
While testing #20991:

- VSCode Version: 1.10.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64
- Node.js Version: 7.5.0

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Run `node --inspect --debug-brk server.js` in shell with simple server.js code.
2. Have the following launch.json configuration:
```json
        {
            "type": "node",
            "protocol": "auto",
            "request": "attach",
            "name": "Attach to Process",
            "address": "localhost",
            "port": 9229
        }
```
3. Run it. The following message is printed: 'Debugging with legacy protocol because Node version could not be determined.'. In addition, legacy protocol does not attach it properly (server.js does not run at all), debug mode terminates automatically without stopping at a breakpoint.

However, launching it in the `"request": "launch"` mode successfully defaults it to v7.5.0.

**Expected Behaviour:**
Determine the running version of inspector.

data.title: SCM view is not helpful when there is no SCM repo
data.body:
Testing #20999 

- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code on a folder which does not have SCM repo initialized
2. Open SCM view
- It is not helpful to figure out that you can initialise the repo from there. 
- Top right icon looks like a Git label rather than an action button
- Commit box and changes take much precedence and misleading
- It would be useful if we can make Initialise action much prominent (like in old git)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10746682/23208744/785c01a2-f8f6-11e6-854c-e5b53b402dfe.png)

data.title: Explorer commands are overly specific
data.body:
testing #20438

There is a conceptual problem with the newly introduced commands. They are very specific to the explorer even though what they do isn't. For instance, `explorer.copyPath` is artificially limited to work only when the explorer has focus. Instead it should also work when invoked from within an editor. In fact, the context menus for the explorer and editor title both contain this command. To configure a single keybinding that copies the path of either the explorer-selection or the current file, I now need two configurations and two separate commands which is illogical and bloat. The same is true for almost all other commands, like open to side, find in folder (of currently active editor), delete file, etc

To stay in the sample, I would suggestion to just have `copyPath` instead of `explorer.copyPath` and in the future `editor.copyPath` because it eases configuration and is logical.

data.title: SCM: delete key should clean the selected file
data.body:
Refs: #20440 

1. scm viewlet, have some changes
2. focus an element, press the `delete` key -> the item should be cleaned or removed from staging
3. this would nicely align with the delete behavior we have in other trees

data.title: End / home key have no effect in quick open
data.body:
Refs: #20440

1. Quick open, use keyboard to navigate through quick open results
2. Press end / home key. They have no effect - I would expect the first / last element in the quick open to get focussed
